questions.text: Identify the arrow-marked structure below:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows the arrow pointing at the fourth ventricle just posterior tothe brainstem and anterior to the cerebellum.

CSF flows via the cerebral aqueduct (between the third and fourth ventricles)into the fourth ventricle.

It then leaves the ventricular system via twoforamina of Luschka at the sides of the inferior aspect of the cerebellum and the foramen of Magendie ;at the back of the inferior cerebellum.

Important Structures:

Explanation of other options:

Lateral ventricle (Option A): Located higher in the cerebral hemispheres, not in the posterior fossa.

Corpus callosum (Option B): Lies superior to the third ventricle, forming the roof, and appears as a thick white matter band.

3rd ventricle (Option C): Located between the two thalami, more anterior and superior compared to the 4th ventricle.

questions.text: Which MRI technique is used to localise Speech Centres in the Brain?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Functional MRI is based on the BOLD technique, Blood Oxygen Level Dependent (BOLD) technique and is used to localise speech centres and Brain Mapping

Other uses:

  • Measures brain activity by detecting changes in blood flow and oxygenation.
  • Visualises functional changes in real-time during tasks or rest.
  • Offers insights into neural processes and connectivity.
  • Used for mapping brain regions related to specific functions.
  • A valuable tool in neuroimaging for clinical and research purposes.

Explanation of other options:

Diffusion weighted MRI (DWI) (Option A) is based on Brownian movements. It detects Cytotoxic oedema before Vasogenic oedema.

Diffusion Restriction - Bright signal on DWI, low Apparent Diffusion Coefficient (ADC)

Diffusion Tensor Imaging (Option B) is Tractography. It uses anisotropic movements. It evaluates White matter tracts.

MR-Spectroscopy (Option D): Evaluates Chemical Metabolites in the Brain

questions.text: Identify the Congenital Anomaly given in the MRI image of a 2-month infant presenting with generalised tonic-clonic seizures and developmental delay ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The following image shows a Figure 8 appearance seen in Lissencephaly (agyria).
  • It is due to defective neuronal migration in the period between the 8th & 14th weeks, resulting in a lack of development of Gyri and Sulci.
  • The appearance of lissencephaly on MRI includes a smooth brain surface with an abnormally shallow sylvian fissure, giving the brain an hourglass or figure-of-eight appearance.

Explanation of other options:

Schizencephaly (Option A) has unilateral or bilateral clefts within the cerebral hemispheres.

Holoprosencephaly (Option B) gives a Pancake appearance on radiological imaging.

Porencephaly (Option D) has Cysts or Cavities within the Cerebral hemispheres involving Encephalomalacia.

questions.text: A one-month-old child was brought by his parents because of Seizures. On paediatrician evaluation, bulging fontanelles and Macrocephaly were noticed, a CT Scan was ordered, which showed the following findings. What is the Probable Diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image, along with the above clinical features, indicates Dandy-Walker malformation.
  • The CT image shows a large cystic area that occupies the posterior fossa, communicating directly with the enlarged 4th ventricle.
  • The Dandy-Walker malformation consists of a cystic expansion of the fourth ventricle in the posterior fossa and midline cerebellar hypoplasia, which results from a developmental failure of the roof of the fourth ventricleduring embryogenesis.
  • An enlarged posterior Fossa with an elevation of the Lateral venous sinuses and the Tentorium is also noted.

Explanation of other options:-

In Arnold Chiari malformation (Option A), part of the Posterior fossa of the brain herniates into the Spinal Cord.

Vein of Galen malformation (Option C) has a triad of hydrocephalus, midline vascular swelling and CHF.

Joubert Syndrome (Option D) has elongated superior cerebellar peduncles showing molar tooth sign, deep interpeduncular fossa and cerebellar vermis hypoplasia. It is also associated with nephronophthisis.

questions.text: Identify the type of haemorrhage shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • An EDH is a collection of blood between the calvaria and outer (periosteal) layer of the dura.
  • EDHs are biconvex in shape. Adherence of the periosteal dura to the inner calvaria explains this typical configuration.
  • Extradural hematoma
    • Biconvex / lentiform / lemon-shaped appearance seen
    • Limited by suture lines, does not cross sutures
    • Due to rupture of the middle meningeal artery
    • Fracture of pterion (H-shaped suture)
    • Causes brain stem haemorrhages called Duret haemorrhages,uncal herniation and causes third nerve palsy
    • Has a lucid interval

Explanation of other options:

SDH (Option B): Happens due to rupture of Bridging veins. Usually, caused by trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants. Crescentic clots ( Banana shaped ) are observed. Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls.SDH crosses suture lines

Intraparenchymal haemorrhage (Option C): Most common type of ICH. Mainly caused by hypertension. Radiologically presents with hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma. Most common site: putamen of the basal ganglia .

SAH (Option D): Appears as hyperdensity within the subarachnoid spaces, such as cisterns and

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be seen due to rupture of a saccular aneurysm in the brain?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The subarachnoid spaces (SASs) are CSF-filled cavities that lie between the arachnoid and the pia. Haemorrhage into the SAS is known as subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH).
  • Sometimes, blood in the SAS is refluxed into the cerebral ventricles, producing secondary intraventricular haemorrhage. The typical location of SAH (basal cisterns and sylvian and inferior interhemispheric fissures). The gross appearance of a SAH is typically characterised by blood-filled basal cisterns.
  • Rupture of an aneurysm typically leads to SAH.
  • The modified Fisher scale is a method for grading SAH as seen on non-contrast CT (NCCT).
  • The Hunt and Hess scale describes the severity of SAH and is used as a predictor of survival.
  • Xanthochromia on CSF is indicative of SAH in case of a negative CT scan.

Explanation of other options:-

SDH (Option A): Usually occurs due to tearing of bridging veins, typically associated with trauma, and appears as a crescent-shaped bleed on imaging.

Hydrocephalus (Option C) can cause increased intracranial pressure and altered mental status, but it usually presents with other symptoms such as headache, nausea, vomiting, and papilledema.

Intracerebral haemorrhage (Option D): Involves bleeding within the brain parenchyma and is commonly caused by hypertension or vascular malformations, not aneurysm rupture.

questions.text: The most common location of hypertensive intracranial haemorrhage is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hypertensive intracranial haemorrhagesmost commonly occur in the basal ganglia, particularly in the putamen.
  • Chronic hypertension leads to degenerative changes in the small penetrating arteries in this area, making them susceptible to rupture.
  • Most common site for hypertensive intracranial haemorrhage -Putamen >Thalamus, Pons, cerebellum.

Explanation of other options:

Subarachnoid space (Option A): Typical of aneurysmal rupture, not hypertensive bleed.

Cerebellum (Option C): Less common but can occur in hypertension; more concerning due to risk of brainstem compression.

Brainstem (Option D): Also possible but less frequent than basal ganglia.

questions.text: The common cause of subarachnoid haemorrhage is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most commoncause of subarachnoid haemorrhage isTrauma
  • The;most common non-traumatic cause of subarachnoid haemorrhage isan Aneurysm.
  • Intracranial aneurysm (Berry aneurysm) is the most commoncause of subarachnoid haemorrhage.
  • The rupture of an intracranial aneurysm is the most common cause of spontaneous subarachnoid haemorrhage.
  • Aneurysms typically occur at arterial bifurcations in the circle of Willis and can lead to significant bleeding into the subarachnoid space upon rupture.

Explanation of other options;

Arteriovenous malformation (Option A): AVMs can cause subarachnoid haemorrhage, but are a less common cause compared to aneurysms.

Cavernous angioma (Option B): These vascular malformations are typically associated with intracerebral haemorrhage rather than subarachnoid haemorrhage. It is seen as Popcorn Calcification in MRI imaging.

Hypertension (Option D): While hypertension is a significant risk factor for many types of intracerebral haemorrhage, it is not the most common direct cause of subarachnoid haemorrhage. It is more commonly associated with intracerebral and intraparenchymal haemorrhages.

Key Takeaways:

Popcorn Calcification

questions.text: Which arterial territory is involved in this CT scan image of a patient with an Infarct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • CT shows hypodensity involving the frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes with loss of gray-white differentiation, involving both deep (basal ganglia, internal capsule) and superficial MCA territories.
  • Infarcts involving the complete MCA territory typically result in extensive ischemic damage to the lateral aspect of the cerebral hemisphere.
  • The middle cerebral artery supplies blood to a large portion of the lateral surface of the brain, including areas involved in motor control, sensory perception, language comprehension and expression, and higher cognitive functions.
  • Involvement of the complete MCA territory often leads to dense hemiplegia, gaze preference, and global aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved).

Explanation of other options:-

Anterior Cerebral Artery (Option A): Infarcts involving the ACA territory typically affect the medial aspect of the cerebral hemispheres, particularly the frontal lobes and the parietal lobes' medial aspect. These infarcts may result in motor and sensory deficits, especially in the lower extremities, and may also impact executive functions.

Posterior Cerebral Artery (Option C): Infarcts involving the PCA territory typically affect the occipital lobes and may lead to visual disturbances, including cortical blindness, visual field defects, and hallucinations. They may also affect memory and language functions, depending on the extent of the infarct.

Posterior communicating artery (Option D): Infarcts involving the posterior communicating artery are less common and typically lead to infarction of structures supplied by the posterior cerebral artery. These infarcts may present with similar symptoms to those involving the PCA territory, including visual disturbances and memory deficits.

questions.text: The CT Scan of a patient who presented with worsening consciousness is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given CT scan image shows theMount Fuji sign and indicates the presence of tension pneumocephalus.
  • Mount Fuji sign refers to the presence of air (pneumocephalus) between the tips of the frontal lobes, giving the appearance of Mount Fuji.
  • Tension pneumocephalus occurs with subdural air causing a mass effect over the underlying brain parenchyma, often from a ball valve mechanism causing one-way entry of air into the subdural space.
  • The appearance of this sign often warrants immediate surgery to prevent permanent damage.

Explanation of other options:

Tension Pneumothorax (Option A) presents with the presence of free gas in the thoracic cavity, whereas the given image shows the presence of air in the cranial cavity.

Simple pneumocephalus (Option C) is a benign condition that occurs commonly after head trauma or postoperatively after neurosurgery, and typically, won't show the Mount Fuji sign.

SDH (Option D): Usually occurs due to tearing of bridging veins, typically associated with trauma, and appears as a crescent-shaped bleed on imaging.

questions.text: The CT Scan of a patient who presented with Worsening Consciousness is given below. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Explanation

  • The given CT scan image shows the Mount Fuji sign and indicates the presence of tension pneumocephalus.
  • Mount Fuji sign refers to the presence of air (pneumocephalus) between the tips of the frontal lobes giving the appearance of Mount Fuji.
  • Tension pneumocephalus occurs with subdural air causing a mass effect over the underlying brain parenchyma, often from a ball valve mechanism causing one-way entry of air into the subdural space.
  • The appearance of this sign often warrants immediate surgery to prevent permanent damage.

Explanation of other options:

Tension Pneumothorax (Option A) presents with the presence of free gas in the thoracic cavity, whereas the given image shows the presence of air in the cranial cavity.

Simple pneumocephalus (Option C) is a benign condition that occurs commonly after head trauma or postoperatively after neurosurgery, and typically, won't show the Mount Fuji sign.

SDH (Option D): Usually occurs due to tearing of bridging veins, typically associated with trauma, and appears as a crescent-shaped bleed on imaging.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristic signs is most commonly seen on contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) in a patient with Cerebral Venous Thrombosis (CVT)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Empty Delta sign:

  • Seen on contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) of the brain in superior sagittal sinus thrombosis (SSST).
  • On CECT, contrast outlines the triangular superior sagittal sinus, but the centre appears unenhanced due to the presence of thrombus- hence the term "empty."
  • This triangular filling defect with peripheral enhancement resembles the Greek letter delta (Δ), giving the name "empty delta sign."
  • An empty Delta sign is seen in CECT in case of Superior Sagittal Sinus Thrombosis.

Explanation of other options:

The delta sign (Option A) is seen in NCCT of Superior Sagittal Sinus Thrombosis.

Banana sign (Option C): Refers to cerebellar tonsillar herniation in spinal neural tube defects like Chiari II malformation, not CVT.

Lemon sign (Option D): Describes the inward scalloping of the frontal bones on fetal ultrasound in spina bifida, unrelated to cerebral venous thrombosis.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman came to the Ophthalmology OPD with complaints of eye pain and Double vision. On history taking, she also said loss of balance and muscle weakness. An MRI was taken, and the following findings are given. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The MRI (FLAIR) image shows the presence of Dawson's fingers, and the correlating clinical history is suggestive of Multiple Sclerosis.
  • Dawson's fingersare radial streaks or lines extending perpendicular to the ventricles in the brain, which are visualised on MRI. They represent areas of demyelination in the white matter of the CNS, which is a hallmark finding in multiple sclerosis (MS).

Explanation of other options:

Parkinsonism (Option A) primarily involves motor symptoms such as tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia. Radiological findings typically include loss of dopamine-producing neurons in the substantia nigra, which can be visualized using functional imaging techniques such as DaTscan (Dopamine Transporter (DAT) SPECT scan (e.g., DaTSCAN), which typically shows reduced dopamine transporter uptake in the putamen and caudate nucleus) or PET scan (may show basal ganglia hypermetabolism).

Progressive supranuclear palsy(PSP) (Option C) presents with specific neurological symptoms such as progressive impairment of balance, gait, and eye movements. Radiological findings may include midbrain atrophy,particularly the 'hummingbird sign' on MRI, which refers to atrophy of the midbrain resulting in a bird-like appearance on axial imaging.

Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (CJD)(Option D) is a rare and rapidly progressing neurodegenerative prion disorder with distinctive clinical features such as rapid cognitive decline, involuntary movements, and other neurological symptoms. Radiological findings may include characteristic changes on MRI, such as high signal intensity in the basal ganglia and/or cortical ribboning, also known as the 'cortical ribbon' or 'cortical ribboning' sign.

questions.text: The typical MRI appearance shown below is seen in:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image depicts 'hot cross bun' sign is a characteristic MRI finding seen in multiple system atrophy(MSA), particularly the cerebellar subtype (MSA-C).
  • This sign appears as hyperintensity in the pons on axial MRI slices, resembling the shape of a hot cross bun.
  • It reflects degeneration and atrophy of pontocerebellar fibresand is considered a specific imaging marker for MSA-C.

Explanation of other options:

Hallervorden-Spatz disease (Option A): This is a genetic disorder characterised by abnormal iron accumulation in the brain, particularly in the basal ganglia. MRI findings may include the 'eye of the tiger' sign, which appears as a central region of hyperintensity surrounded by a rim of hypointensity on T2-weighted images

Multiple System Atrophy- P (Option C): This subtype of multiple system atrophy is characterised by predominant Parkinsonism. MRI findings may include ;atrophy of the putamen, cerebellum, and brainstem, but the 'hot cross bun' sign is more commonly associated with MSA-C. MSA-P shows Putaminal rim Sign.

Wilson's disease (Option D): This genetic disorder results in abnormal copper metabolism and can lead to copper accumulation in various organs, including the brain. MRI findings may include changes in the basal ganglia, such as hyperintensity on T2-weighted images, due to copper deposition. Additionally, copper accumulation in the liver may result in hepatomegaly and hepatic dysfunction.

questions.text: 'Tram track' calcifications in NCCT head are characteristic of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sturge-Weber Syndrome is a neurocutaneous disorder characterised by a facial port-wine stain (nevus flammeus), leptomeningeal angiomas, and glaucoma.
  • The 'tram track' calcifications seen on NCCT Head are due to calcification of the abnormal blood vessels along the cortical surface of the brain.
  • These calcifications follow the gyri and sulci of the brain, giving a tramline appearance.

Explanation of other options:

Congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection (Option A): Radiologically shows, Periventricular calcifications, which are characteristic but do not present as tramline patterns.

Congenital toxoplasmosis (Option B): Radiographic findings incule intracranial calcifications, which are typically scattered and can be diffuse or focal, not in the tram line pattern.

Craniopharyngioma (Option C): Radiographic findings include calcifications are common and may be seen on plain X-rays or CT scans. These calcifications are typically irregular and localised to the sella turcica region, not presenting as tramline patterns.

Key Takeaways:

Tram track signs :

  • On CXR - Bronchiectasis
  • On Light Microscopy - MPGN type 1
  • On NCCT Head - Sturge-Weber Syndrome
  • On Mammography \ USG - Duct Ectasia

questions.text: Which vessels are catheterised in Carotid angiography?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Carotid angiography is used to study the blood vessels that supply the brain (ie,internal carotids and vertebral arteries).
  • Incarotid angiography, both internal carotid arteries are catheterised, along with one vertebral artery.
  • The fourth vessel, which fills by reflux, typically refers to the contralateral vertebral artery or the contralateral internal carotid artery, depending on the injection technique and the patient's vascular anatomy.
  • This approach allows for the visualisation of the entire cerebral vasculature, including the major vessels that supply the brain..

Explanation of other options:

2 external carotids and 2 vertebrals (Option A): External carotids are not primarily evaluated in carotid angiography.

2 internal carotids and 2 vertebrals (Option B): Although informative, 4-vessel catheterisation is uncommon due to redundancy via reflux.

2 external carotids and 1 vertebral (Option D): External carotids are not routinely catheterized in cerebral angiography.

questions.text: Calcification in the basal ganglia is seen in?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Calcification in thebasal ganglia is typically seen in
  • Hypoparathyroidism can lead to hypocalcemia, which may result in the deposition of calcium in various tissues, including the basal ganglia of the brain.
  • Basal ganglia calcifications are a characteristic finding in hypoparathyroidism.
  • Calcification of the basal ganglia is seen in hypoparathyroidism, pseudohypoparathyroidism and also in hyperparathyroidism.
  • Pathogenesis is unknown, but its occurrence with hypocalcemia suggests that increased calcium-phosphorus complex formation plays a role in hypoparathyroidism.

Explanation of other options:

Hypothyroidism (Option A): It is more commonly associated with diffuse brain atrophy rather than focal calcifications.

Hypopituitarism (Option C): It is more commonly associated with hormonal deficiencies due to pituitary dysfunction.

Hypoaldosteronism (Option D): Hypoaldosteronism is not typically associated with basal ganglia calcification. It is primarily associated with electrolyte imbalances, particularly sodium and potassium levels.

Note:

Fahr's Disease (Familial Idiopathic Basal Ganglia Calcification) is an Autosomal dominant condition characterised by Abnormal deposition of Calcium in the Basal Ganglia

questions.text: The 'doughnut' sign seen on a brain scan usually suggests?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The "doughnut sign"or ring-enhancing lesions are characteristic of various brain pathologies, including abscesses, metastases, and glioblastomas.
  • These lesions are identified by a central area of low density (necrosis or fluid) surrounded by a ring of high density(enhancing tissue due to increased vascularity and inflammation).
  • Therefore, the correct answer encompasses all the options provided.

Doughnut sign/ring enhancing lesions in brain scan are seen in ;

  • Cerebral abscess (Option A)
  • Tuberculoma
  • Neurocysticercosis
  • Metastasis (Option B)
  • Glioblastoma (Option C)
  • Subacute infarct/hemorrhage/contusion.

The Double Doughnut sign is seen in Dengue Encephalitis, causing Acute Necrotising Encephalopathy.

questions.text: Multiple punched-out lesions on X-ray are seen in?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Punched-out lesions are sharply demarcated, round areas of bone loss without surrounding reactive sclerosis, best seen on skull or axial skeletal radiographs.
  • These lytic lesions result from increased osteoclastic activity and are characteristic of multiple myeloma, a malignant plasma cell neoplasm.
  • Multiple myeloma commonly presents with bone pain, anaemia, renal dysfunction, and hypercalcemia.

Explanation of other options;

Paget's disease (Option A): Paget's disease of bone typically shows a mix of osteolytic and osteosclerotic changes, with bone expansion and cortical thickening.

Craniopharyngioma (Option B): Craniopharyngiomas are benign tumours that occur near the pituitary gland. They may cause calcifications visible on X-ray, but not the punched-out lesions characteristic of multiple myeloma.

Eosinophilic granuloma (Option D): Eosinophilic granuloma, part of Langerhans cell histiocytosis, can cause lytic bone lesions, which may sometimes resemble punched-out lesions. However, the condition more typically affects the skull, ribs, spine, and long bones in children and young adults, but it is less commonly associated with the multiple, widespread punched-out lesions characteristic of multiple myeloma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with recurrent headaches. An MRI was ordered, and the following findings were seen on the MRI. What is the most probable diagnosis based on the MRI given?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The given image and the female with a history of headaches are suggestive of ;Meningioma. It's arising fromthe Falx in the midline.
  • Meningiomas are non-glial neoplasms arising from meningocytes of the Meninges.
  • They may containEstrogen & Progesterone receptors.
  • Meningiomas have a Dural tail sign - Broad base towards the Dura
  • Mother-in-Law Sign - Early Enhancement and Delayed Washout
  • NF-2 Gene mutationoccurs on Chromosome 22 and is associated with Acoustic Neuromas, Meningiomas and Ependymomas.

Explanation of other options:

Acoustic Neuroma (Option A): Vestibular Schwannoma/Acoustic Neuroma arise in the Cerebello-pontine angles and present with SNHL. They show an Ice-Cream cone appearance on contrast-enhanced MRI.

Pituitary Macroadenoma (Option B) has a Figure of 8 or Snowman appearance and presents with Bitemporal Hemianopia.

Craniopharyngioma (Option D): Craniopharyngiomas are benign tumours that occur near the pituitary gland. They may cause calcifications visible on X-ray, but not the punched-out lesions characteristic of multiple myeloma.

questions.text: A 42-year-old chronic alcoholic male is brought to the casualty with symptoms of unsteady gait and altered mental status. On clinical examination, he has ophthalmoplegia and nystagmus. An MRI was done and has the following findings. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • On MRI, there is symmetrical hyperintensity of the periventricular grey matter, mammillary bodies, medial thalami, midbrain tectum, and periaqueductal region, suggestive of Wernicke's encephalopathy.
  • Wernicke's encephalopathy is a neurological disorder due to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, commonly seen in chronic alcoholics.
  • Classic triad includes ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and confusion.

Explanation of other options:

Parkinson disease (Option A): In Idiopathic Parkinson's Disease (PD), MRI is usually normal but may show hypointensity in the substantia nigra on T2-weighted or susceptibility-weighted imaging due to iron deposition. DAT-SPECT scan shows reduced dopamine transporter uptake in the putamen and caudate, confirming dopaminergic deficit.

MSA type-C (Option B) shows the presence of the Hot Cross bun sign. The given image doesn't resemble MSA type-C and shows ;periventricular grey matter seen in Wernicke's Encephalopathy.

Huntington's Chorea (Option D) has Boxcar ventricles. The given image doesn't resemble Huntington's Chorea, and shows periventricular grey matter seen in Wernicke's Encephalopathy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male, who is retro positive, presents with complaints of Headache, Altered mental status and Fever. Radiological imaging revealed the following findings. What is the Probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image shows a soap bubble appearance, indicating Cryptococcosis.
  • CNS cryptococcosis results from infection of the central nervous system with the yeast-like fungus Cryptococcus neoformans.
  • Initial management includes Liposomal Amphotericin-Bcombined with Flucytosine, followed by

Explanation of other options:

Cerebral Toxoplasmosis (Option B) has ring-enhancing lesions, whereas a soap bubble appearance is seen in Cryptococcosis.

Primary CNS Lymphoma (Option C) is an AIDS defining illness. But it doesn't show a Soap bubble appearance.

Tuberculous meningitis (Option D) has Exudates in the basal cisterns. The given image doesn't resemble Tuberculous meningitis.

questions.text: CT Scan of a 12-year-old child shows the following findings. She is having clinical symptoms of high-grade fever, altered sensorium and seizures. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image shows involvement of the bilateral thalami and basal ganglia.
  • Based on the radiological and Clinical findings given, the probable diagnosis isJapanese encephalitis.
  • On CT scan, it shows symmetric or asymmetric bilateral thalamic hypodensities.
  • This pattern is considered pathognomonic in the appropriate clinical setting (fever, altered sensorium, seizures in a child from an endemic region).

Explanation of other options:-

Acute infarct (Option A): Typically presents as unilateral involvement in a vascular territory, not bilateral thalamic lesions. Acute infarct shows light bulb sign on DWI.

Tuberculous meningitis (Option C) has Exudates in the basal cisterns. The given image doesn't resemble Tuberculous meningitis.

Internal cerebral vein thrombosis (Option D), on CT, shows hyperdense areas with dense clot sign and cortical oedema.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male came to the casualty with impaired Cognition and abnormal movements. When asked, attenders gave a history of rapidly progressive Dementia and Personality changes over 6 months. MRI showed the following findings. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The MRI DWI image shows hyperintensities in the cortex (cortical ribboning) and basal ganglia, which are characteristic of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD).
  • CJD is a prion disease and presents with rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, ataxia, and extrapyramidal features.
  • MRI findings are key for early diagnosis: cortical ribboning and basal ganglia hyperintensity on DWI/FLAIR sequences.
  • Variant CJD shows the Hockey stick sign, the Pulvinar sign..

Explanation of other options:

Alzheimer's disease (Option B): Presents with slowly progressive memory loss. MRI shows global cerebral atrophy, especially of the medial temporal lobe.

Hallevorden-Spatz disease (Option C) (now called Pantothenate Kinase-Associated Neurodegeneration or PKAN) often involves the globus pallidus and substantia nigra, leading to the 'eye of the tiger' sign on MRI, which is different from the diffuse white matter involvement described here.

Huntington Chorea (Option D) shows Boxcar Ventricles because of the involvement of the caudate lobes.
